00059 /** To be used from printfs, to control screen poss **/
00060 #define SCREEN_CLEAR "\x1B[2J"
00061 #define SCREEN_CLEAR_LINE "\x1B[K"
00062 #define SCREEN_MOVE_CURSOR_TO  "\x1B[%d;%dH"
00063 #define SCREEN_RESET  "\x1B[0m"
00064 #define SCREEN_BLACK  "\x1B[30m"
00065 #define SCREEN_RED    "\x1B[31m"
00066 #define SCREEN_GREEN  "\x1B[32m"
00067 #define SCREEN_YELLOW "\x1B[33m"
00068 #define SCREEN_BLUE   "\x1B[34m"
00069 #define SCREEN_WHITE  "\x1B[37m"

00071 /// counts how many erros have been detected. Normaly it shall be 0
00072 extern unsigned long errorCounter;
00073 
00074 /// register the error message of the last Error occured: ist is a uniq pointer too
00075 extern const char* errorMsg;

00079 /** Writes 0 terminated  1/0 string representing the input 
00080  * value, takes the lower 'len' bits
00081  * warning: it writes in outbuf 'len' bytes + a terminating 0 (len +1)
00082  * @param[in]  val 4-byte to be represented as list of bits
00083  * @param[in]  len number of bits used within val
00084  * @param[in/out]  outBuf buffer to write string 
00085  * @return  outBuf buffer to write string
00086  */
00087 char* formatBinary(long val, int len, char* outBuf);
00088 
00089 /** Printf protected with a semaphore: Thread safe 
00090      Warinig: %3.9f means 3 digits then . then 9 digits
00091  **/
00092 void PRINTF(const char* fmt, ...) __attribute__((__format__(__printf__,1,2)));
00093 
00094 
00095 
00096 /** prints only if negligibleLevel <= printfVerbosity, Important msgs have lower negligibleLevel **/ 
00097 void PRINTF_CONDITIONAL(int negligibleLevel, const char* fmt, ...) __attribute__((__format__(__printf__,2,3)));
00098 
00099 
00100 /** Writes an error text with a leading title to stdout and keeps 
00101  * a counter. Used to report programming errors which shall be corrected.
00102  */
00103 void ERROR(const char* text);
00104 
00105 /** Print a character bitwise, highest bit first. 
00106  *  obsolete! use %b in PRINTF
00107  *  @param[in]  val 8-bit value to be printed
00108  **/
00109 //void printBin(unsigned char val); obsolete: use %b in PRINTF
00110 
00111 /** Prints an array of bytes as hex values 
00112  *
00113  * @param[in] titel leading text in the line printed before values
00114  * @param[in] ptr pointer to array to be printed as unsigned char
00115  * @param[in] len number of characters, respectively bytes in the array
00116  */
00117 void printCharsHex(const char* titel, void* ptr, unsigned int len);
00118 void printCharsHex_Conditional(int negligibleLevel, const char* titel, void* ptr, unsigned int len);
00119 
00120 /** Function to read a character from stream, in case one has been written.
00121  * Normal getchar (in linux) will stop the complete execution. 
00122  * In order to avoid waiting first isCharRaedy() is called.
00123  * The implemetation is platform dependend defined in getcharnowait.cpp.
00124  *
00125  * @return latest character read, -1 if no character is available
00126  */
00127 char getcharNoWait();
00128 
00129 /** Checks if a new character has been received from stdin.
00130  * Associated to getcharNoWait().
00131  * Returns true if a new character is available in order to read it with getcharNoWait.
00132  *
00133  * @return 1 if a new character is in the buffer, 0 otherwise
00134  */
00135 bool isCharReady();
00136 
00137 /**
00138  * Get a string using getcharNoWait().
00139  * Returns If a string is ready it returns a pointer to it, else it returns 0 (no wait).
00140  * The maximal length of a string is 120 chars (due to internal buffers).
00141  * The String will not be modified until the next call
00142  * to getsNoWait.
00143  * Not Thread save. Only one reader from stdin is allowed.
00144  * Else... I dont know, try what it does and let me know.
00145  */
00146 char* getsNoWait();
00147 
00148 /**
00149  * if you activate the topic cat input, all input string from
00150  * terminal will be distributed to the topic charInput
00151  * until you call a getcharNoWait() or getsNoWait();
00152  */
00153 
00154 void activateTopicCharInput();
00155 
00156 /**
00157  * Like in linux fflush(stdout)
00158  */
00159 void FFLUSH();
